entry.title: Notes | Combine Label Propagation and Simple Models Out-performs Graph Neural Networks
entry.summary: Under review as a conference paper at ICLR 2021.
entry.content:
Under review as a conference paper at ICLR 2021.

Problem

Many ideas of new GNN architectures are adapted from new architectures in models for language (e.g. attention) or vision (w.g. deep CNNs) with the hopes that success will translate to graphs. However, as these models become more complex, understanding their perfoemance gains is a major challenge, and scaling them to large datasets is difficult.

Core Idea

A post-processing model is proposed for node classification. Base Prediction + Label Propagation (Correct & Smooth).

The key idea is that we expect errors in the base brediction to be positively correlated along edges in the graph.

Correct and Smooth Model

  1. Notations
  • Undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E), where there are n=∣V∣n=|V|n=∣V∣ nodes with feature matrix X∈Rn×pX \in \mathbb{R}^{n\times p}X∈Rn×p.
  • Adjacency matrix AAA of graph GGG. Diagnal degree matrix DDD. Normalized adjacency matrix S=D−1/2AD−1/2S=D^{-1/2}AD^{-1/2}S=D−1/2AD−1/2.
  • Node set VVV is split into a disjoint set of unlabled nodes UUU and labled nodes LLL. LLL is further splited into a training set LtL_tLt​ and validation set LvL_vLv​.
  1. Simple base prediction
  • Train a model fff to minimize ∑i∈LtLoss(f(xi),yi)\sum_{i\in L_t} Loss(f(x_i), y_i)∑i∈Lt​​Loss(f(xi​),yi​), fff is either a linear model or a shallow multi-layer perceptron.
  • From fff, a base prediction Z∈Rn×cZ \in \mathbb{R}^{n\times c}Z∈Rn×c can be obtained.

    In principle, we can use any base predictor for ZZZ, including those based on GNNs.

  1. Correcting for error in base predictions

    Errors in base prediction to be positively correlated along edges in the graph.

    An error at node iii increases the chance of a similar error at neighboring nodes of iii.

    Define an error matrix E∈Rn×cE\in \mathbb{R}^{n\times c}E∈Rn×c:

    ELt=ZLt−YLt,ELv=0,EU=0E_{L_t}=Z_{L_t}-Y_{L_t}, E_{L_v}=0, E_U=0 ELt​​=ZLt​​−YLt​​,ELv​​=0,EU​=0

    Then smooth the error using the label spreading technique:

    E^=arg⁡min⁡W∈Rn×ctrace(WT(I−S)W)+μ∣∣W−E∣∣F2\hat E=\mathop{\arg\min}\limits_{W\in \mathbb{R}^{n\times c}} trace(W^T(I-S)W)+\mu||W-E||^2_F E^=W∈Rn×cargmin​trace(WT(I−S)W)+μ∣∣W−E∣∣F2​

    The solution can be obtained via the iteration E(t+1)=(1−α)E+αSE(t)E^{(t+1)}=(1-\alpha)E+\alpha SE^{(t)}E(t+1)=(1−α)E+αSE(t), where α=1/(1+μ)\alpha=1/(1+\mu)α=1/(1+μ) and E(0)=EE^{(0)}=EE(0)=E, which converges rapidly to E^\hat EE^. Then add the smoothed errors to the base prediction to get corrected predictions Z(r)=Z+E^Z^{(r)}=Z+\hat EZ(r)=Z+E^.
    However, the propagation cannot completely correct the errors on nall nodes in the graph, as it does not have enough "total mass" because of:

    ∣∣E(t+1)∣∣2∣∣≤(1−α)∣∣E∣∣+α∣∣S∣∣2∣∣E(t)∣∣2=(1−α)∣∣E∣∣2+α∣∣E(t)∣∣2||E^{(t+1)}||_2||\le (1-\alpha)||E||+\alpha ||S||_2||E^{(t)}||_2=(1-\alpha)||E||_2+\alpha||E^{(t)}||_2 ∣∣E(t+1)∣∣2​∣∣≤(1−α)∣∣E∣∣+α∣∣S∣∣2​∣∣E(t)∣∣2​=(1−α)∣∣E∣∣2​+α∣∣E(t)∣∣2​

    When E(0)=EE^{(0)}=EE(0)=E, ∣∣E(t)∣∣2≤∣∣E∣∣2||E^{(t)}||_2\le||E||_2∣∣E(t)∣∣2​≤∣∣E∣∣2​. In the end, two variations of scaling the residual are proposed.

    • Autoscale. Zi,:(r)=Zi,:+σE^i,:/∣∣E^:,iT∣∣1Z_{i,:}^{(r)}=Z_{i,:}+\sigma \hat E_{i,:}/||\hat E^T_{:,i}||_1Zi,:(r)​=Zi,:​+σE^i,:​/∣∣E^:,iT​∣∣1​ for i∈Ui \in Ui∈U, where σ=1∣Lt∣∑j∈Lt∣∣ej∣∣1\sigma=\frac{1}{|L_t|}\sum_{j\in L_t}||e_j||_1σ=∣Lt​∣1​∑j∈Lt​​∣∣ej​∣∣1​.
    • Scaled Fixed Diffusion (FDiff-scale). E(t+1)=[D−1AE(t)]UE^{(t+1)}=[D^{-1}AE^{(t)}]_UE(t+1)=[D−1AE(t)]U​ and keep fixed EL(t)=ELE^{(t)}_L=E_LEL(t)​=EL​ until convergence to E^\hat EE^. And it still effective to select a scaling hyperparameter to produce Z(r)=Z+sE^Z^{(r)}=Z+s\hat EZ(r)=Z+sE^.

  2. Smoothing final predictions

    Set the training nodes back to their true labels and use the corrected predictions for the validation and unlabeled nodes.

    GLt=YLt,GLv,U=ZLv,U(r)G_{L_t}=Y_{L_t}, G_{L_v,U}=Z^{(r)}_{L_v,U} GLt​​=YLt​​,GLv​,U​=ZLv​,U(r)​

    Then iterate G(t+1)=(1−α)G+αSG(t)G^{(t+1)}=(1-\alpha)G+\alpha SG^{(t)}G(t+1)=(1−α)G+αSG(t) with G(0)=GG^{(0)}=GG(0)=G until to convergence to give the final prediction Y^\hat YY^.

    The motivation is that adjacent nodes in the graph are likely to have similar labels, which is expected given homophily or assortative properties of a network.

Summary

To review our pipeline, we start with a cheap base prediction ZZZ, using only node features but not the graph structure. After, we estimate errors E^\hat EE^ by propagating known errors on the training data, resulting in error-corrected predictions Z(r)=Z+E^Z^{(r)} = Z + \hat EZ(r)=Z+E^. Finally, we treat these as score vectors on unlabeled nodes, and combine them with the known labels through another LP step to produce smoothed final predictions. We refer to this general pipeline as Correct and Smooth (C&S).

entry.title: Notes | Boost Then Convolve: Gradient Boosting Meets Graph Neural Networks
entry.content:
ICLR 2021

Introduction

  • GNNs have shown great success in learning on graph-structured data.
  • GBDT are successful for tabular data.
  • This paper proposes a novel learning architectures for graphs with tabular data, BGNN, that combines GBDT with GNN.

Background

  • GNN: a mapping function gθ:(G,X)→Yg_{\theta}: (G, X)\rightarrow Ygθ​:(G,X)→Y, which utilizing the graph's topology.
  • GBDT: a iteration structure of trees ft(x)=ft−1(x)+ϵht(x)f^t(x)=f^{t-1}(x)+\epsilon h^t(x)ft(x)=ft−1(x)+ϵht(x).

BGNN

  1. Problems
    • How to train GBDT and GNN jointly?

    Indeed, optimizations of GBDT and GNN follow different approaches: the parameters of GNN are optimized via gradient descent, while GBDT is constructed iteratively and the decision trees remain fixed after being constructed (decision trees are based on hard splits of the feature space which makes them non-differentiable).

  2. Core idea
    • Train a new decision tree in each epoch to correct the input of GNN.
  3. Model Architecture
  4. Implementation Details
    • Pass to GNN module is trainable.
    • The target for the next decision tree in Step 5 is the difference between the optimized node features X′X'X′ in Step 2 and the feature f(X)f(X)f(X) in Step 1.
  5. Interpretation
    • GBDT as an embedding layer for GNN.
    • GNN as a parametric loss function for GBDT.

    In the former case, GBDT transforms the original input features XXX to new node features X′X'X′ which are then passed to GNN. In the latter case, one can see BGNN as a standard gradient boosted training where GNN acts as a complex loss function that depends on the graph topology.

Thinking Points

  • Flexible combination of different algorithms.

entry.title: Notes | Graph-Based Kinship Reasoning Network [ICME 2020]
entry.summary: Accepted to ICME 2020(IEEE International Conference on Multimedia & Expo 2020) as an Oral Presentation.
entry.content:
Accepted to ICME 2020(IEEE International Conference on Multimedia & Expo 2020) as an Oral Presentation.

Title

Graph-Based Kinship Reasoning Network

Problem Description

Giving two face images, determing whether these two people have kinship.

Core Idea

  • Construct a Kinship Reasoning Graph.

Network Architecture

  1. ResNet-18 for extrcating image features.
  2. GNN on a kinship reasoning graph.
  3. MLP and Softmax for prediction.

Implementstion Details

  1. ResNet -18
    • Using sharing weights CNNs for feature extraction.
    • The two output vectors are feature representations on the same feature space.

    Since we use the same CNN to extract features for two images, the values of two features in the same dimension represent the comparison of one kind of kinship related information encoded in that dimension.

  2. Kinship Reasoning Graph
    • Feature Nodes (peripheral nodes): the values on the same dimension are defined as a feature node.

    We use one node in the kinship relational graph to denote the comparison of one feature dimension.

    • Super Node (central node): a central node created to connect feature nodes.

    Therefore, we create a super node that is connected to all other nodes while all other nodes are only connected to the super node.

  3. GNN
    • Using the same parameter WmessW_{mess}Wmess​ to transform node features int messages.
      mk=RELU(WmessThk−1)m^k = RELU(W_{mess}^T h^{k-1})mk=RELU(WmessT​hk−1)

  4. MLP
    • MLP([hcK∣∣h1K∣∣...∣∣hdK])MLP([h_c^K || h_1^K || ... ||h_d^K])MLP([hcK​∣∣h1K​∣∣...∣∣hdK​])

Data Flow

  1. Feature Vectors 2×5122\times 5122×512
  2. Gaph Layer 0, feature Nodes 512×2512\times 2512×2, super Node 1×21\times 21×2
    • Wmess∈R2×512W_{mess} \in \mathbb{R}^{2\times 512}Wmess​∈R2×512
